The House just passed H.R. 5, the Regulatory Accountability Act.  I am cosponsor of this bill because it fights back against judicial deference and insufficiently checked-and-balanced federal regulations.   The bill contains six titles: • Title I: Regulatory Accountability Act - Requires agencies choose the most affordable rulemaking alternative that meets statutory objections, calls for greater public input, and better vetting of critical information used to make regulations. • Title II: Separation of Powers Act - Repeals the Chevron Deference doctrine that forces courts to defer to the regulatory and statutory interpretations of bureaucrats. • Title III: Small Business Regulatory Flexibility Improvement Act - Agencies must account for the direct, indirect, and cumulative impact of new regulations on small business and find flexible ways to reduce the negative impacts. • Title IV: REVIEW Act - Prohibits new billion-dollar rules from taking effect until courts can review and resolve all timely-filed litigation. • Title V: ALERT Act - Requires agencies to publish online, timely information about regulations in development that include their expected nature, costs, and timing. • Title VI: Providing Accountability Through Act - To encourage public understanding, new proposed rules must include plain-language online summaries.

Yesterday, President Donald J. Trump signed my legislation H.J.Res. 57 into law.  I introduced this resolution to rescind Obama administration’s regulations implementing accountability provisions in the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) that would have allowed the Department of Education to expand its reach.   The rule disregarded Congressional intent and would have taken authority away from local school corporations and given it back to Washington.  This law undoes that rule, making sure that local education leaders have the ability and flexibility to craft plans for their schools that address the unique needs of their students.  The previous Washington-knows-best approach to education has officially ended, and I am proud of our work here to ensure that our nation’s education system is working for students, not federal bureaucrats.

June is National Safety Month.  National Safety Month focuses on reducing the leading causes of injury and death at work, on the road and in our homes and communities.  To improve workplace safety, I introduced the Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Act, which would make the VPP permanent.  The VPP was created in 1982 to promote effective worksite-based safety and health but has yet to be codified into law.  My bill would do so.  In the VPP, management, labor, and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) establish a cooperative relationship at workplaces that have implemented a comprehensive safety and health management system. Approval into VPP is OSHA’s official recognition of the outstanding efforts of employers and employees who have achieved exemplary occupational safety and health.  Currently more than 2,200 worksites participate in the program covering approximately 900,000 employees.  A 2007 report noted that VPP saves at least $89 million in public sector costs annually due to reduced injuries.  Additionally, private sector employers report a 100-300 percent return on investment on their VPP participation.

Today we celebrate the 70th Anniversary of India’s independence.  I am a member of the Congressional Caucus on India and Indian-Americans because I recognize the importance of good relations with India and the contributions that Indian-Americans have had to our country and our state. Cintas of Frankfort is a full-service corporate apparel facility.  Cintas has been named one of the “Most Admired Companies” in the United States and visiting the facility I can see why. I have introduced H.R. 1444, the Voluntary Protection Program Act, to codify this program.  The bill has 34 bipartisan cosponsors.

The Indiana Farm Bureau is dedicated to strengthening Hoosier farmers. They advocate for biotechnology and advancement, an economy that works for Hoosiers, and tax reform to help Hoosier farmers keep more of their hard-earned money.  I spoke at Kevin Underwood’s West Lafayette Farm about how I plan to continue helping Hoosier farmers. Kathy and I are praying with those affected by this horrible tragedy. I stand in support of Spain as the country heals, and I encourage everyone around the world to take the threat of terrorism seriously.

Improving Indiana’s infrastructure is a priority of mine. The opioid crisis is a national health emergency that knows no bounds. It is affecting men, women, children--all ages, all races. In Indiana, a recent pilot program from the state Department of Health found that about 1 in 5 infants assessed at hospitals around the state tested positive for opiates. We must work together to stop it from worsening and taking the lives of more Hoosiers, and more Americans.   Tomorrow as Chairman of the Subcommittee on Early Childhood, Elementary, and Secondary Education, I will be leading a joint subcommittee hearing “Close to Home: How Opioids are Impacting Communities” to hear about keeping the opioid crisis from further infiltrating our homes, schools, and businesses. Happening Now: Joint House Committee on Education and the Workforce subcommittee hearing on the opioid crisis and how it is impacting our communities.  As Chairman of the Subcommittee on Early Childhood, Elementary, and Secondary Education, I will be co-chairing this hearing.  The opioid crisis is claiming the lives of 175 Americans per day.  Today's hearing is an opportunity to come together to discuss ways to help kids who might be struggling like Brady Noonkester, a Hoosier who lost his life to opioids. If we repeal the individual mandate, we would be giving the people choice and saving $338 billion in taxpayer dollars.
